utterances: Thank you very much.
Hey, what's up?
How are you feeling, bro?
Well, thank so much for having me.
Oh, yes.
We do worry about that.
I mean you do not want to see people come back again, but they do come back in.
We have this term that we used that is use in the airline business called frequent flyers.
Frequent flyers are people who come back in after they've had it once, they've had it twice, they've had it three times.
And there are multiple people who have multiple bouts of gunshot wounds, and every time they'd come in it makes it more difficult for us to sort of save them and bring them back.
But I always try to take an advantage of what's called a teachable moment.
And so when they're in the hospital, they actually are listening at that point.
They may not listen afterwards but I try if I can to give them a message about, you know, you can change things.
And I've seen a number of the younger ones begin to change their life as they've had these terrible things happen to them.

I always try, if I can, to influence them in a positive way by being someone who a lot of times look like them, because a lot of the gunshot wound victims that I see in San Francisco are African-Americans.
So when they look at me, I hope that even though I have a white on and I'm quite official that they see that there's hope for the future, that you can do something good with your life.
Walk us through a typical day in San Francisco General, in the operating rooms where you operate.
There are two types of days for me.
There is days where I have elective surgery.

So there are routine days where I come in, get to the operating room and I work in the operating room all day doing elective operations like gall bladders, hernia repairs, colon resections, stomach resections and other things like that.

And there are days where I'm on call or I'm on service where that means that I have to respond within a few minutes to the emergency department, where I have to run down and I have to begin my care for the patients.
So a trauma surgeon is someone not in the emergency room.
Physicians or trauma surgeon is someone who cares for someone when they hit the door to the months or the years afterwards that they get cared for.

I have people I'd operated on 10 years ago, they come back and they see me and I could - I'll check them out and make sure they're OK and do the right thing for them, which is one of the reasons why I became a doctor was because I wanted to, you know, ride on my white horse and save the day, and I really get a chance to do that.
When I'm a trauma surgeon, I could walk to work and I could see anything, and it really is pretty amazing the stuff that I see on a daily basis.
You know, this could be considered one of the most depressing jobs in the world, but as you're talking I hear this almost childlike sense of excitement about what you do.
You're still excited by this, aren't you?
Oh, yes.
Everyday, it's exciting.
It's fun.
It's challenging.
I get to work to try to do good.
So I mean I really, you know, when - I do a lot of teaching of medical students.
I'm working with the next generation of physicians.
That's some of the most exciting things that I do on a daily basis, try to let them understand there are times that you have to feel it.
So if something bad happens, you have to feel it, you have to process it and you have to acknowledge them.
And I do a lot of things with music.
I'm a big jazz fan.
So when I'm in the operating room, I'll put on some Miles Davis or John Coltrane.
I mean I enjoy what I do on a daily basis.
One of the articles - the article said that I have a very good deep laugh and I laugh quite a bit…
Well, you do have a great voice.
Oh, thank you very much.
You can call me Barry White, Farai.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Absolutely.
Dr. Barry White to you.
Exactly.
Well, that's a great place to leave it, and we certainly wish you well and all of the lives that you affect.
Dr. Campbell, thank you so much.
Oh, thank you very much and I really appreciate you allowing me to come in your program and talk about the good things I get to do on a daily basis and saving people's lives and making a difference.
Dr. Andre Campbell is a trauma surgeon and chief of the medical staff at San Francisco General Hospital.
He's also a professor of surgery at the University of California San Francisco.
He spoke with NPR'S Farai Chideya.
(Soundbite of music)
That's our show for today.
Thanks for being with us.
To listen to the program visit npr.org.
NEWS & NOTES was created by NPR News and the Africa-American Public Radio Consortium.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
a congressional report due this week says the Iraqi national police force is such a mess, the organization should be dissolved.
First, President Bush in Iraq today on an unannounced visit.
The president made the trip just a week before his two top advisors there - General David Petraeus and US Ambassador Ryan Crocker - present their assessment of the war to Congress.
Mr. Bush was on a trip to Australia.
The plane detoured so he could make a quick visit to Iraq.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Defense Secretary Robert Gates are traveling with the president.
Earlier, I spoke with NPR's Don Gonyea, also onboard Air Force One.
We're at the Al-Asad Air Base.
It's the second largest US base in all of Iraq.
It's home to some 7,000 Marines and another 3,000 US personnel.
And we're located about halfway between Baghdad and the Syrian border, in the middle of the desert.
This is not at all like the president's first two unannounced trips to Iraq when he went to Baghdad each time and went into the Green Zone.
We're really - it feels like we're in the middle of nowhere out here - just sand and heat as far as the eye could see.
Riots erupted today in Germany near the site of next week's summit of the Group of Eight.
Tens and thousands of demonstrators descended on the northern city of Rostock.
They were mostly peaceful, but some masked protesters attacked police with rocks and bottles, leaving 140 officers hurt.
Fracking.
But the president was greeted, when he came off the plane, by General Petraeus and by Ambassador Crocker.
And he started with meetings with them.
And the White House says it's a chance to get a firsthand, face to face in person report from them on how things are going.
It's not clear what the president will hear here that he hasn't heard from them already, but the White House stressed that it's important to meet face to face.
And then he's also having meetings with Iraqi leaders, including Prime Minister Maliki, whom the White House has been trying to put some pressure on to move political reforms along.
And maybe the key part of this is that Prime Minister al-Maliki is out here in this part of Iraq.
This is a Sunni area of Iraq, western Iraq.
And he's a Shiite leader.
And it's something, I guess, the White House thinks to get Mr. al-Maliki out to this area.
Maybe a kind of a symbolic coming together of these two disparate communities, anyway.
That is absolutely part of it.
One of the frustrations with the Iraqi central government led by Maliki is how slow reconciliation between the various factions within the government have been coming along.

Now, the White House likes to point to Anbar province as an area where the Sunni tribal leaders in the last year decided that it is in their best interest to work with the United States aggressively, to form militias and to fight al-Qaida, which had seen this as a real stronghold for some time.
So the way the White House describes it is - what you're seeing in Anbar province as kind of reconciliation from the bottom up, coming from the provincial level.
Now they're trying to get Maliki to kind of reach out to them, so you have top down reconciliation as well.
It's going to be a difficult task.
But the White House, going to - sees in that model something that the rest of Iraq look to.
You've said that the White House has told you that the president wants to see General Petraeus and Ambassador Crocker face to face in this setting.
Is there some other overall goal that the White House has set for this trip?
Well, you know, the debate is coming up in Congress, the president's Iraq policy.
And it is just, you know, to put it very bluntly, a policy that's in trouble.
Democrats have - for a long time - been opposed to it.
But what's been happening over the course of this year is that moderate Republicans and even not so moderate Republicans have been starting to peel off and abandon the president.

So you can really see this trip as speaking to them, highlighting an area -Anbar province - where there is some progress, giving them something to kind of hope for and maybe, maybe stick with the president a while longer on this as this debate really gets cranked up in the fall after General Petraeus testifies next week.
NPR's Don Gonyea, traveling with President Bush on a trip to a meeting in Australia, with a side trip today to Iraq.
Don, thank you.
My pleasure.
I'm Ed Gordon, and this is NEWS AND NOTES.
On this week's fitness challenge, a low-impact exercise anyone can do: walking.

NPR's Farai Chideya laced up her shoes and hit the streets of New York and Los Angeles to see if her feet were made for walking.
Plus, NEWS AND NOTES nutritionist Rovenia Brock explains why walking is both good for the mind and the body.

Okay, so I've got my pedometer on.
I'm ready to go.

And I've gone about half a mile.
All right, I'm getting ready to pass the Radio City Music Hall.
What is amazing is that in the same way that taking the subway is faster than taking a cab, sometimes walking is the fastest thing of all.
Because right now, the traffic is bananas.

(Singing) I'm walking.
Yes indeed, and I'm talking…
Okay.
I went and I had a pedicure at 56th and 6th, and now I need to check into a hotel.
I could try to take a bus, but the traffic looks awful, so I'm just going to walk.
And probably, that is going to be eight blocks downtown and about three really long blocks cross-town.
So I'm off again.
